Visited in May. The prime rib is more expensive than you get at your cheap Vegas eateries, and it is a higher quality, for sure, but not so high of a quality that you have an orgasm. It's better, but you pay for that, although not obscenely. The restaurant is well run, they do a good job. I had a basic prime rib meal, nothing exotic, and it was worth paying a little more for the better quality cut of prime rib and higher quality service. It's worth another indulgent meal next time I go to Vegas.

After seeing Dennis Miller in the Orleans showroom (Dennis rocked - the showroom is a whole other Yelp) I was pretty hungry I didn't feel like waiting until I got back to the Strip to eat. I discover the hidden Prime Rib Loft. You take stairs from the casino floor up to, well, a loft. Thus is the Prime Rib Loft. A kind of dark restaurant hidden away in an off strip casino. However, due to the location, you get to stare at the Orleans' creepy faux Mardis Gras float heads as you dine. I wish I would have taken a picture to share - it's almost surreal.   The food: as you can tell by the name this is a vegan restaurant. Not a single dead animal on the menu - nawh, just kidding. The name says it all. A basic dinner: a salad (I had the Cesar - not bad), a decent cut of beef, and your choice of baked or mashed. It's not great but it's solid. It's what you expect. That's never a bad thing!   The wine list was surprisingly good considering the restaurant. I had a by the glass Malbec that went well with the beefy dinner. The only actual disappointment of the night was the dessert - the cheesecake was a bit dry and tasteless. Oh well, it's not called the Cheesecake Loft is it?   Also, the prices are quite reasonable.   Bottom line: is it worth a $20 taxi ride from the strip? No. But if you happen to be in the Orleans - it's a pretty good meal at a reasonable price!

I've been going to the prime rib loft for nearly a decade and have recommended it time after time again to friends and clients alike who always walked away happy from their meals. Now I'm not a big yelper but I wanted to reach out somehow to the loft in hopes that things will change for the better.   Change is what they have done. They've changed the decor from the dark and misty cellar ambiance you'd find in a steak house in New Orleans to a bright, less authentic, setting.   After the initial shock of he decor change I brushed it off because the food is awesome and my favorite dish in this town is their Oscar filet. Not only was the filet removed from the menu but there was not a filet period.   The menu used to be a sturdy book menu that you'd find in traditional steak houses but this was replaced with a thin paper menu that totally took away from the luxury.   The bread- petty I know but I love carbs- was different and transferred from delicious buttery rolls to bread sticks. Again, luxury removed.   Lastly, the carb fan inside me again emerges, mashed potatoes were not offered where they traditionally had been. I'm sorry- when I go to a steak house I want masked potatoes. Instead baked and au gratin were offered which is strange considering mashed potatoes are cheaper for the house to make.   In short- the loft used to be an amazing place to eat if you wanted to spend a little more on a popular local haunt. The changes they have made are a huge let down to its legacy and whoever is responsible for these changes does not deserve this place and the legacy they have ruined.

We had dinner here last night. We shared a medium size cut of prime rib, medium rare and it was done perfectly. We shared a baked potato and one half was the size of a normal potato. The salad was very fresh and a good size. I'd recommend sharing if you are not a big eater; it was more than enough. Unfortunately we didn't have room for dessert; but those looked yummy too.

Absolutely terrible doesn't being to describe our experience, despite the restaurant being dead on a Friday night. Sub-par food and some of the worst service I've ever experienced. The waiter acted like us being there was an inconvenience to his life. About the food...  Asparagus fries were $8.50 for 5 fries. Best tasting  part of the entire meal but way too small of a portion.   House salad looked like it came out a stale bag of lettuce from the dollar general, with a huge slop of ranch dressing on top. There was about 6x the amount of dressing needed. All either of us could taste was ranch dressing. It was actually really good dressing but that's beside the point.   Baked potato was lukewarm and the server put so much butter and sour cream I couldn't taste anything else. Au gratin potatoes looked like they had been sitting all night on the warmer and my girlfriend had one bite before refusing their brown cheesey garbage again.   Both of our cuts (Gamblers + Cajun) were extremely fatty and nothing to write home about. I'd estimate about 1/3 of each was pure fat and thrown out. We recently dry aged some prime rib roast at home for 3 days and it was amazing. These 21 day dry aged cuts didn't have anywhere near the flavor of what we made at home in 3 days.   When we were clearly ready to get boxed up, our server and his assistant went to the back and mysteriously vanished. Waited about 8 mins before the manager asked if we wanted to get boxed up and we could finally get the hell out of there.   I'd probably leave 0 stars if I could but let's call it one star for the asparagus fries and some really good ranch dressing.

If you're going out for prime rib in Las Vegas this is the spot to go. The service is excellent prices are good manager caters to every need. The bartender is excellent makes the drinks nice and strong for the price. I would highly recommend this place to anybody who wants local prices with Las Vegas strip style type of food. This is a nice getaway from the strip steak prices not too far off of the strip with local prices. Try it out and see what you think it's like being on the strip without all the hassle of traffic and strip prices.

Chalk this up to "it looked better on Open Table than it turned out to be."  The good: there's no shortage of beef when you order the prime rib. It's a tad chewy compared to what you might find closer to the Strip, but it does come out to order  The ambiance in the room is that of a Holiday Inn dining room. It's low-roller nice, not high-roller nice, and service is good but not that of a fine dining restaurant (which this really isn't.) The same music playing in the casino plays overhead, complete with announcements about slot tournaments and the Players Club.  But they're not charging Strip fine dining prices for the experience of parking your car yourself and walking past the TGI Friday's and Fuddruckers in the casino to get here either. So if you want a big hunk of beef and you set your expectations accordingly you can have a nice meal.

While the decor is a little dated, it seems to fit pretty well at the Orleans! We called ahead for a reservation (on a Wed night) but realized we didn't need one when we arrived because they were empty. The servers were prompt and very friendly - a nice change from other casino restaurants! i ordered the prime rib and my wife ordered the steak and lobster special. Both dishes were cooked perfectly and arrived with a huge baked potato loaded with butter, sour cream, chives, and bacon. For the price, I would say it's the best prime rib I have had in Vegas (and the lobster was excellent too!). If you order prime rib, make sure you get their horseradish. It is so hot that it will make anyone cry!

Last night was our second time dining at the loft. We were seated in the balcony area overlooking the players table below. Knocking off one star only because my medium rare prime rib was a little tough around the edges, but the center was delicious. Creamed corn is yummy. Shrimp cocktail is tasty as well. Overall, the service was good, food was great, prices were amazing. We will be back... :)

I recently visited this restaurant for the first time and was both pleasantly surprised by the food quality and utterly dismayed over the attitude of our server.  The restaurant is truly a "loft", located upstairs inside the Orleans Hotel and accessible either by stairway or elevator.  I was running late for my reservation and they were able to accommodate happily, adjusting somewhat my reservation by 15 minutes.  That, however, is almost where the great service stopped.  Overall, the main dining area approximates elegance, but there were many families dining with children and the prices aren't exorbitant.  The prime rib is available in several cuts, escalating in size and price.  Steaks are also available and all is cooked to order.  The night I visited they had a special for a smallish steak and two lobster tails for a very reasonable price.  In addition to a complimentary bread mix there are also several appetizers available - we ordered the stuffed mushroom caps and they were good but not great.  The only real negative for me was our server.  After asking the fantastic busboy about our cocktail order, we were directed to ask our server.  The restaurant has a full bar, but there is only a wine and beer list available at the table, so no mention of specialty cocktails.  When our waiter arrived he was unshaven and dour.  When I asked if they could make a Bahama Mama (a fairly common rum cocktail), the waiter stared blankly and said he'd never heard of it.  He did inquire and they were able to make the drinks, but our waiter never once smiled or engaged us in any way other than the most perfunctory of requests required to get our orders.  Basically, his attitude was a wet blanket on what otherwise would have been a really fine meal.  While I can eagerly recommend the restaurant, I would also request other seating if this guy was ever our server again.

Not impressed at all.  I had heard about this restaurant and even though it was located off the strip at the Orleans I decided to give it a try knowing that I wanted prime rib and it's their specialty.   Unfortunately the service was ok, prime rib underwhelming and not at all tasty.    It's a older restaurant, but also wasn't expecting anything to fancy but I guess I just expected a great prime rib but instead it was nothing special.

We went searching for a new steakhouse to try and a friend told us about the Prime Rib Loft. The atmosphere is very nice, the murals fit with the general feel of The Orleans. Prime rib isn't my first choice so I had the New York strip. Maybe this is where I went wrong. If you are looking at patronizing this restaurant I would lower your expectations. Think: less steakhouse, more Applebees. The salad was typical of a house salad: watery lettuce and a few olives. No big deal, it's to be expected at a steakhouse. The steak itself was very dry. The server asked us if needed A1. This should have been a red flag. A good steak should never require any additional seasoning. The steak was cooked medium and had the appropriate amount of coloring. Taste itself was pretty bland and disappointing. It needed some pepper or basic seasoning. It seemed to me that the steak was finished cooking before other people's and they left it under the heat lamp too long. Unacceptable, especially at the price. I really love the mashed potato cart, it's rare to find restaurants that still do this. Overall, I would say the atmosphere is good but the quality is disappointing. The service was decent but if they got busy I would worry. There are so many great steakhouses in this town, this place is not one of them.

The Prime Rib Loft at the Orleans Casino The Prime Rib Loft exemplifies attention to detail, something sadly overlooked in many restaurants nowadays. From the moment you ascend the gracefully curving stairway to the dining room, you are subtly soothed and relaxed, likely without even being aware of the cause. From the calming patterns of the flagstones set in the walls of the stairwell to the subdued red teardrop shaped lamps lighting the hand painted Jazz Band murals lining the walls you find the stresses of life and that tenseness of your posture slowly easing and a relaxed smile brightening your visage. For those desiring it, one wall of the dining room offers a lofty vantage of the main casino floor, allowing the diners to remain aloof from the noise and bustle yet still enjoy the ebb and flow of the vibrant casino life. I was pleased to note that I could not detect even the faintest hint of cigarette smoke despite my location above the casino, a credit to the architects or interior designers in my opinion.     After being seated by the charming hostess, I was immediately offered a glass of water kept constantly full from unique styled bottles rather than the standard, boring pitcher. The water hadn't the slightest hint of chemical taint so often found in public restaurants. Along with the water, I was treated to a basket of fresh, hot rolls, one type of which was a delicious pretzel bread and a ramekin of soft, sweet whipped butter.  Finding myself relaxed, at ease and feeling decidedly pampered, my server Jose arrived to inquire if I would like to order. He skillfully assisted me in narrowing my choices to the exact correct meal with the perfect choice of wine.  I have to assume the blue cheese dressing for my salad was crafted in house as it had the perfect blend of creamy dressing to blue cheese crumbles, creamy and flavorful without being overpowering. The salad had a nice blend of color with a clever flatbread garnish and a chilled salad fork.  Jose displayed his superior skills by not hovering but being readily available and, most importantly, his timing, delivering my entrée after I had completely finished my salad and had a few moments for it to settle. Again, this is something many people seem to be oblivious to, but I greatly respect. Having my meal unceremoniously dumped in front of me when I am half done with my salad, soup or appetizer, in my opinion, displays both discourtesy and a lack of experience or skill. Among other things, it makes me feel rushed and leaves me deciding if I wish to waste half my salad or attempt to enjoy cold food.  The prime rib was absolutely perfect! Done exactly as I requested, coated with an incredible blackened seasoning with a delightful bite to it and containing exactly enough fat to ensure a marvelous flavor and meat that is moist and tender, without leaving an enormous clump of fat as is so common with lower grades of prime rib. The au jus was obviously fresh and well made, light and flavorful, not the thick, dark, salty liquid I can only assume comes from a can that is so commonly provided.   The reasonably priced domestic Merlot suggested by Jose was the absolute perfect complement to the dinner!  A flawless experience is rare in the extreme, and I have to admit that in this case, I found the garlic mashed potatoes moderately uninspiring with little noticeable garlic flavor. The baked potato may have been a preferable choice, though I would honestly have preferred it if replacing the starch with a vegetable selection had been an option. Ala carte vegetable dishes were available for additional cost (and I should note that I found the price of the prime rib extremely reasonable at less than twenty dollars) but with the popularity of low-carb diets, I would think replacing the starch portion would be an option.   For the perfect finish to the meal, I chose the daily dessert option, which today was Black Forest Cake. Fortuitously, this is one of my favorite desserts and I was not disappointed in the slightest. This was served with a modest chocolate syrup drizzle for a garnish, not swimming in a pool like many places. The cake had a perfect moist, puddingy texture.   In summary, what would have been a delicious dinner transcended into the realm of a dining experience purely as a result of the details. The attentive, friendly staff, the ambiance, the timing, the chilled salad fork, the water in bottles, the softened butter; these are the things that exemplify a quality restaurant over the common corporate eateries. In a state of near reverence from the dining experience, I took the time to speak with the manager, Susan, and compliment both Jose's outstanding service and her obviously skillful management. It was the service above and beyond the normal that prompted me to write this review.

"The Prime Rib Loft" needs to improve on their customer service.  If your reading this your probably hungry and looking for a good place to eat. So the question your asking is this place any good. The food is okay. The prime rib was a bit too dry and bland. Still eatable. The baked potato was AMAZING. Sadly that's all I have to say because I had a horrible, embarrassing experience here and I invite you to read my experience at "The Prime Rib Loft".   THE NOT SO GOOD, THE BAD AND THE UGLY  GETTING A TABLE: I dinned here with my family a party of 6 on Saturday at around 8:30 on a not so busy night. So getting a table won't be a problem, we were seated right away after our reservation was honored.   SERVICE - Let me start by saying I work at a restaurant here in Las Vegas, so I have the experience and knowledge to recognize good or bad service. Our experience at this restaurant was overall: disappointing.   Our server took her sweet time in greeting us, taking drink orders and finally 30 minutes later the dinner order. Ok no problem, no need to be rushed. Suddenly I noticed we were being ignored by out server. Refills were not handled at a reasonable time, and salads took more then expected to arrive. The busser/food server assistant was the only professional worker there. Finally after probably 30 more minutes after our salad our dinner arrived and by then, our party lost their appetite after feeling neglected after waiting so much. The manager was not helpful at all. There was a prime rib at our table that was served warm, so we flagged the manager and we asked him why did our dinner take so long? They replied with one of the most stupid excuses, "because we are busy". I've learned that this excuse it's irrelevant to the guest, it doesn't fix the problem it only makes the guest feel like a dumbass! After that the manager failed BIG time! He brought out a smaller prime rib and I told my friend, "didn't you order a larger cut?"   So enough was enough, I was disappointed and embarrassed that the manger and waiter couldn't rise to the challenge at making the rest of our dinner outshine their mistakes. The manager comped a few things and never offered a dessert menu. Sucks because we were celebrating a 60th birthday, and we told them twice!   I walked out embarrassed at receiving one of the most dullest, laziest customer experiences. Thankfully the food wasn't half bad.   To conclude I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone. I know it's located at The Orleans and you shouldn't expect greatness. But can I ask you "The Prime Rib Loft" to put a smile on, and give better service and to turn on some music, lol. Everyone here looked like they didn't want to work.   1 star for the Food a Server Assistant 1 star for the BAKED POTATO

What a gem in Vegas. This recent Thanksgiving 2014 trip, bro and I were going to go to Gallagher's or some other fancy steak place, until a good friend told me to try this place at the Orleans. We were not disappointed. The price point was reasonable - the meal included salad, sides, and necessary sauces. I got the 1.5 lb prime rib medium rare and bro the 14 oz. NY steak. The prime rib is gargantuan of pure reddish beef, not too salty, just tender and flavorful. I took the bone home to trim and give to Fido for his enjoyment. Au jus is just the right amount of saltines, nothing too salty or bland. Creamy horseradish sauce a delectable accent, and the garlic mashed potatoes were plentiful and unique. I did not even eat all of the mashed potatoes. I got to try some NY steak and at medium, it had a great char and tender flavor. I would have ordered it med.-rare if I ordered it, but bro likes it a bit more done. Nonetheless, the steak is a true NY steak and aged well.  At this place, a prime rib is a prime rib, and a NY steak is a NY steak -- why state the obvious you ask? Because in my other review of Sam's Town Firelight buffet, they were passing off prime rib AS NY steak. I thought it was really funny that they do so. Therefore, I add pictures here so there can be no doubt which is which.  A big filling meal for two big guys, just under $60 before tip (no alcohol)...cannot go wrong. Very close to THE Steak House in Circus Circus in value, taste, and presentation, although, we missed the charming accent of the attractive and shapely Eastern European hostess at THE Steak House.  Décor was New Orleans style, kinda old school, but the place was large enough and since we went on a Monday evening, quiet. Service was impeccable and prompt. As far as value for this price point, here in Vegas, it cannot be beat. Next time when we raise the price point a notch or two, then that's a different level of comparison.  Try this place! We were not steered wrong (no pun intended), just an honestly-priced place for pure beef.

I had quite the experience years ago with my family. I went back hoping they could rekindle that awesomeness that I experienced back then.   I went with my mom and dad that time. They sat us and our waiter greeted us. They provided us bread and too our order shortly after. They didn't have the corn chowder that I found to be so awesome before, so instead we got the Mexican soup. As my main entree, I ordered the flat iron steak with a lobster tail green beans, and garlic mashed potatoes. I enjoyed my steak along with my lobster tail and sides, even though it may not be 5 star restaurant quality. For the price, it is definitely worth it and a nice place to eat if you don't want to break the bank.

Dinner 4-23. Had shrimp cocktail, house salad, 10 Oz prime rib. Shrimp was tasty and cocktail suace was spicy and had a hint of mustard. House salad was ok. Too much ranch for my liking. Tried the ceasers salad and it was very anchovy. Prime was cooked exactly as ordered and came with a nice side of mashed potatoes. Would go here again. Really reminded me of old school vegas

I had such a bad experience here.  Walking into the place I already had a bad vibe.  The host was very rude, no friendly greeting.  She brought us to a booth.  Waited at least 15 mins for a server to serve us water. He did not  say anything to us at all.  Poured water all over the table.  Then 5 mins later finally a server came to take our order.  This server comes to us and said "What are you having"  mind you, he did not introduce himself to us, did not apologize for us waiting so long. Then when we started to order our steak, we ordered the beefeater, medium rare. Medium rare steaks are a little bloody if some of you don't know that because the server assujmed we had no idea what medium rare steaks areHe had to ask us at least 3 times if we wanted our steak a little bloody. After  be walked away, I was so upset because eating at a decent steakhouse or at any restaurant, you would like to be treated with a little respect. These employees decided to treat us like crap because of how we dressed or how we looked like. Never will I set foot into that restaurant and I will never recommend that place.

Very good prime rib, decent price, and clean and quaintly atmosphere. The service is good yet a bit timely in bringing the food out yet it taste great so I guess you can't rush quality. Was not a 5 because though food was god the environment was missing something, just not warm for a 5.

It's off the strip- so be excited for more reasonable prices.  It's not anything over the top, but it's pretty good for what you pay.  You get a salad and a potato with your meal.  We got the prime rib of course, and I was really impressed with the au jus on the actual plate, as well as the horseradish.  They give you both prepared, and creamy so you can choose.  Also, they make the potato table side which I think is a nice touch.  For $28 in Vegas... it's totally worth it.  We'll be back, Vegas is our happy place.  :)

Sorry this is a year late, but I had to share the photo's.  Both me and the wife really enjoyed our experience here and the food.  I started with a salad and wifey wanted to try the artichoke hearts.  We actually shared them, they came in a pair.  We were so devouring one, we almost forgot to take a pick.  Wifey never had them like this before and she loved it.  She used to think she didn't like artichokes!  The aioli was delicious and paired perfectly with the grilled artichokes.  My caesar salad was attractively composed and not over dressed and the veggies were all very fresh and crisp and the Parmesan twist was a nice touch, but I think they forgot the croutons, see pic, lol.  Faye-sy's rib was excellent, and perfectly cooked and the baked potato was huge!  I love how they wheel out your meal on a cart, your food covered to keep it warm, and your server will ask you how you want your potato dressed!  The works, of course!  lol  My chops were also excellent.  I love lamb, and they were perfectly medium done, with that lovely char crisp sear on the outside.    If we make it to Vegas again, we will make this a must stop.  Fine dinning for a casual price!
Best deal for prime rib in Vegas. A hidden gem for sure. The beefeater is at least two meals so come hungry. The lamb chops are also excellent. Great service.

i gotta admit, i read the reviews and went anyway. i usually dont read the 4 and 5 star reviews, i read the 1 and 2's to see what they REALLY have problems with. so, i knew right away, dont order the stuffed mushrooms.someone mentioned they serve voss water, it's not voss....it's tap and served warm with no ice.  i ordered the creamed corn (saw too many foodtv people making it from scratch that i wanted some). it was canned corn with some crappy cream sauce and it was lukewarm at best. the salad was terrible. i mean, how do you mess up a salad? my sea bass was lackluster. not much flavor at all. the garlic mashed potatoes same thing....no flavor.....hey....ever hear of salt and pepper? it's good and goes on food! the service was above awful. took 15 minutes to get a server (although i did read in one review it took a while, and when they seated us, they said it would be a few minutes.....not 15)...she didnt' ask how our salads and soup were, and as soon as she served the dinner, pretty much before we had a bite, she asked how it was. not a place i would return to.....even if it's free. id rather cook at home than eat here.

Really liked this place - upstairs and out of the way from the Casino floor at the Orleans Hotel - see my review for the Orleans here - http://www.yelp.com/biz/orleans-hotel-and-casino-las-vegas-2?hrid=vTE6wKknvjq_4Mf_crpTpQ  So back to this place - a bit smaller but able to handle groups pretty easily, fully stocked bar with great service   On the night I visited with my group of 10 people we were sat quickly on a Saturday night at 8pm - having a reservation helped though but they weren't so crowded that we were stuck waiting. Food service was quick and food was great - everyone in the group was happy.  Pricing is great as well and affordable - this is defiantly a place to come to eat

I was so disappointed this use to be one of our favorite places, prices have gone up and quality has gone way down. It reminded me of Cafe Food at a much higher price. We got the Orleans cut 10 Oz prime rib hardly any flavor and  tough meat, the tempura vegetables were like drinking oil, the bread was not that fresh, the vinegrette dressing was like eating sugar it was so sweet. The Lobster tail I added on for $20 was mushy and butter came cold in a plastic cup. Service was OK, I will not return.

The Orleans is a fantastic casino to play slots to gamble in. No joke. But on to the food... one night while trying to avoid a buffet, we ended up here and having no expectations at all, the prime rib turned out to be a surprising find!  Skip the appetizers and go straight for the entrees with come with a house salad plus a baked potato or garlic mashed potatoes.  The Orleans cut is 10 oz and the Gamblers Cut is 14 oz.  They also have a gigantic 24 oz on the bone if you have a hearty appetite. Our server said the Gambler's Cut is the most popular.  Overall I thought the prime rib was tender and juicy  (au jus on the platter); they also give you a large side of horseradish which complements the meat. I don't know what 21-day aged prime rib tastes like?  But that is their claim! Their servers serve everything on a rolling cart with silver covered platters.  It is pretty old school, but it works.   Funny, but their Chambord berries and vanilla ice cream was a delicious dessert that was a large serving. There were a few servers helping our area and they were all pleasant and worked at a steady pace.   Every few mins we'd see a rolling cart go by and it seems they have system down.  If you're off strip and feel like prime rib, try this place out.  Don't drink their wine; gave me a slight headache, so it is prob the cheap kind in giant bottles. Otherwise, if you want another recommendation- they have a pretty darn good breakfast buffet in this casino for cheap!

I always going to the prime rib loft when I am in Vegas for my annual bowling tournament. Prices are cheap, prime rib is always good and there is never a wait. It is very casual that you can go in shorts and sandals and they don't ever mind that we are really drunk and annoying.

Once each trip to Vegas I splurge for a really nice dinner.  Sometimes I get disappointed, not here,  I showed up just after opening and it wasn't very busy yet.  Not being a fan of prime rib I chose the Filet of beef Oscar ($25).  I always hesitate to order medium rare as many chefs under cook it and it takes a good piece of meat to pull it off.  My waitress convinced me it was ok to order it that way and I was very pleased with the result.  It included a salad, which I had with blue cheese dressing, and my choice of potato, I chose garlic mashed.  I also had a slice of one of the best pieces of cheesecake I have ever had (I think $7).  The only regret I have is the Kendall Jackson glass of wine, I should know better as I have never had a K-J wine I really liked.  A note: a "glass" of wine is really a third of a bottle carafe so it isn't really as expensive as it seems.  Not only was this a great meal, at $44 plus tax and tip it was relatively inexpensive for Vegas.  I noticed a good portion of the diners were locals.
The food was great and the staff was nice. The only thing is that our food took forever to come. We got there at 7pm and got our food at 8:30p and the restaurant wasn't even crowded.

Shockingly good for a restaurant not on the strip.  It's located in the Orleans Hotel, I think on Tropicana.  Its not far from the strip, right past In-N-Out for all you Hawaii peeps.  My bf tells me that this is the best place to eat prime rib.  He has a straight face.  I ponder this thought: I don't particularly like prime rib (quiet your gasps), but we go anyway.  He, of course, has the prime rib.  I have a slice, and it was great.  Very moist, cooked perfectly medium rare as we like it, and very tasty,  What a good choice.  I had some type of shrimp pasta thing - scampi, I think.  The flavor was good, but sauce was a little overpowering.  What did I expect?  It's a prime rib loft.  No stars deducted.  The salad that I had was phenomenal.  It was just a regular starter salad, but the dressing....OHhhhhh, it was a raspberry vinaigrette, and it was GOOD.    It's a relatively small restaurant, and it overlooks the rest of the casino.  Get it?  Loft.  The prices are very reasonable.  The service was good and employees were friendly.  No TV, so if you're betting on the game, don't eat until after.

When Friend #1 had a $25 food credit for one of the restaurants at The Orleans, Friend #2 and I picked this restaurant.  We were greeted warmly and seated immediately at a both.  The mellow and upscale ambience felt soothing, and our efficient server Donna took our orders as soon as warm rolls and butter hit the table.  Our shared appetizer came out fast, but started the meal off SO badly:  Lump Crab Stuffed Mushroom Caps ($12) - 5 deep fried balls served on inedible green leaves of some sort, on top of a bed of crispy rice noodles.  Dijon mustard, some kind of creamy sauce, and warm marinara came alongside.  Talk about an identity crisis!    The mushroom inside the thick fried coating hid under a ball of salty, dry crabmeat.  None of the sauces made any sense at all, nor did they taste good - alone or with the mushroom.  It was so awful that when I told the busser, he sent the manager over.  When I repeated to the manager how awful and dry the shrooms were, he looked down, picked up the plate with the remaining 2 mushrooms, and literally slunk away without a single word of apology or offer to take it off the bill or replace it with something else.  It was a very strange reaction, especially for a manager level person, and we were left pretty much speechless by his odd wordlessness.  When Donna came back with dinner salads for me and Friend #2 and a Jambalaya soup for Friend #1 (they came with our meals), she did apologize for the awful appetizer, which was the first proper acknowledgement we had for it.  Maybe DONNA should be the manager - as she had way better communication skills than their actual one.  Salads were basic - iceberg, red onion, sliced cucumber and diced tomatoes.  The soup of the day was the Jambalaya, which it didn't resemble in chunkiness, and the flavor was totally unimpressive to me.  Both came with a Cheez-It-tasting cracker that was mildly entertaining.  Dinner finally looked up when our entrees arrived:  Me: The Gambler's Cut ($19) - a 14 oz cut of prime rib, rare, with steamed green beans and carrot julienne instead of the mashed or baked potato choice.  My meat was perfectly rare, perfectly fatty, super juicy, flavorful without being overly salty, and the creamy horseradish that came with was great!  The veggies were good too - tender and skinny green beans, still al dente.  Friend #1: The Beefeater Cut ($25) - this 22 oz bone-in MONSTER was a gorgeous hunka meat!  Same meat as mine, only bigger!  My friend got a huge baked potato to go with, and Donna served him sour cream, butter, bacon bits and chives from her serving cart.  Friend #2: The Orleans Cut ($16) - my friend requested this 10 oz prime rib grilled, and Donna didn't bat one lash when taking her order.  It came out with nice grill marks, and still perfectly medium rare as she likes it.  Since we were rushing off to a show, we didn't have time for dessert.  But if I erase all memory of the stuffed mushroom appetizer, I would be open to returning for just the prime rib in the future - and definitely try their Bananas Foster dessert!

Pretty much what we expected after reading reviews. Great Prime Rib w/au jus, potato, salad. Service can be a little weird with foreigners as servers. We mentioned special occasion with our reservation but nothing special done. No acknowledgement.

This is the first time we are trying this place.  So far so good.  We walked in without a reservation right when they open 5pm.  We were sat and our server had just clocked in.  We weren't told any specials because he came straight to the table to greet us and was not told about the specials for the evening.  To us it was okay because we are in the mood for prime rib.    We ordered the southwestern spring rolls.  They are very good.  It came with an avocado and chipotle sauce that was very tasty.  My boyfriend has a salad and I had the chicken orzo soup.  The salad is a salad, and the soup was good.    We both ordered the gamblers cut prime rib. Come from the Midwest, my expectations for prime rib in the west coast wasn't very high.  I would rate the prime rib 7/10. So it's above average.    Overall I'm pleased with my experience here.

I went here because the best restaurant in the Orleans, Canal Street, was closed for the holidays (!). I was pleasantly surprised. It was old-style Vegas. You go up these stairs to a loft area overlooking the casino. There was a mix-up on my reservation but it didn't matter since the place was empty at 9 pm the Monday before Christmas. I was seated in a comfortable booth.     I started out with a good martini, then a non-descript house salad with fresh warm rolls.  The main course was the "Gamblers Cut" 14 oz. prime rib, with a fresh grilled artichoke with lemon aioli dipping sauce, and  garlic mashed potatoes.  The beef, which I ordered medium rare, was thick, tender, and uniformly pink. The artichoke was grilled but still juicy, the potatoes suitably garlicky.  The meal was reasonably priced. I paid with player club points. Service was attentive but nonintrusive. Overall it was a relaxing experience before I hit the tables again.

I really like this place.  I liked it when it was a dark and I like it now with the lighter, upbeat looking decor.  Since prime rib is only on the higher priced buffets, one must search it out at other restaurants.  The Prime Rib Loft fits the bill nicely.  Boyd sent me a food voucher good at four of their properties.  Prime Rib Loft came to mind immediately.  I made a reservation for 5:30 so I had plenty of time for dinner before going to a play at Las Vegas Little Theatre in Chinatown.  I was seated as soon as I arrived and I had a view of the entire restaurant.  At first, the place was very quiet.  Soon, as more people arrived, the energy level picked up and with it the sound but it was never a bother.  I wanted to get the four onion soup but when you get one of their prime rib meals, with it comes corn showier or house salad and either baked or au gratin potatoes.  It's odd you can';t substitute because both soups are the same price.  The option given to me by my server, Rudy, was that I could order the onion soup à la carte and then get a salad.  I didn't go for that.  Too much food.  I ordered the Orleans cut prime rib--their smallest at 10 ounces--the corn chowder, and the baked potato.  He asked me if I wanted it loaded and I said yes.  Butter, sour cream, bacon bits, and chives.  For dessert I got Oreo cookie cheesecake which isn't on their printed menu.  The menu says to look for their daily dessert cart special and this was it for the day I was there.  I was brought a small bread basket.  I was so glad they downsized the amount for one person.  There's nothing I dislike more than waste.  I can always ask for more.  My iced tea was brought quickly and was refilled often.  The corn chowder was blisteringly hot which is good and which was good.  I got some freshly ground pepper on top.  There was plenty of time to slowly eat the hot soup without being rushed with an early arrival of prime rib.  That just didn't happen.  Rudy kept an eye on me and put the prime rib order in at the right time.  I had ordered the rib the rarest they had.  It was rare and it was very tasty.  Before starting, there was a small show table side.  The baked potatoes are on a cart pushed to your table where your server puts in the items you selected.    The meal was very enjoyable and all plates were clean of food when I finished.  After Rudy gave me dessert choices and I picked the Oreo cookie cheesecake, he brought it to the table.  A good size serving and very tasty!  A very nice ending to a good meal.  Service was excellent while I was there.  The table was patrolled for empty sweetener packs and the staff was polite and helpful.  I will be back with or without Boyd food vouchers.  (People at Boyd--disregard that sentence!!!)

We got there bout 15 mins b4 they were closing and they took us.  They only had medium well left for prime rib so 3 out of 4 of us got the T-bone steak instead. Maybe cuz it was closing time and they wanted us to eat and leave that they didn't cook the steak the way we asked which was medium rare. ALL of our steaks came out meduim. =( Comes with soup or salad and baked potato or garlic mash.  It's not the best steak but you get what you pay for. The side dishes of cream of corn and asparagus was pretty good.  I would only go back if i was staying at the hotel and didn't want to drive to some place else.
Love this little hidden gem! Good prime rib for really good prices!!!! A must go when in town.

Came in for dinner around 7:45pm on a Tuesday night. The place can hold a lot of people, sadly there wasn't a lot of people inside.  The corn chowder was really good, loads of flavor and not over salty. I ordered the Beefeater Cut $34(including tax). This 24oz. prime rib cut comes with the bone in. I felt they did a good job of cooking it to my liking (med-rare). However, maybe it was because of the size of the cut, the surface was very flavorful and then bland throughout.

Went on a Monday night and there wasn't a wait at all. The wait staff was very good and attentive despite a couple tables of knuckleheads that were complaining (totally wanted something for free), I believe their names were Ivan and Abbey. All in all it was a great experience for a reasonable price.

Stopped here after Viva 21. The hubby and I where starving decided to stop here for a late dinner. We both ordered the New Orleans cut with a baked potatoes and salad! So I really enjoyed my salad the ranch dressing was so delicious! We got our prime rib with a huge baked potato the waiter comes with cart with a lot of sides for your baked potato and asks what you would like in it. Which is amazing and easier than having to put them on your self! Anyway the prime rib was good but NOT the best that I've had had. I will definitely stop here again if I am in the area :)

If you are in Vegas and you are looking for affordable prime rib, this is the place to go. The night I went they were thrown a major curve ball, but handled it the best they could. The food was pretty good.

I was not expecting a fab meal based on reviews but I was close and hungry. The restaurant was really nice and spacious with a great atmosphere. The staff was great, my server Donna seemed to go out of her way to make sure I was happy. The prime rib was VERY tender. Taste:  pretty good but the BEST part was the garlic mashed potatoes. They were amazing. Real taters but with great flavoring right down to the pieces (minuscule) of garlic. While not the perfectly aged prime rib (which I did not expect; I guess their 21 days should be more?) I would definitely go back again!

I've tried to find a "steak house" I like for many years. I've tried them all -Morton's, Ruth's, Fleming, some independents, and all the usuals. NONE even come close to Prime Rib Loft. And the crazy part is, I've been going to the Orleans Hotel for years and never even knew this place was upstairs. The wine, artichoke, salad, meat, garlic mashed, desserts, service - all the best I've found at a "steak house". The meat was flavorful and tender. And the fact that all the other things that go along with it were great too makes this place a real winner!

This place is a joke. The bread was cold and they only gave us one cup of butter for 4 people to share. We had to ask 3 times for extra butter. The "medium rare" prime rib was mostly medium in the middle and was too tough to eat. The garlic mashed potatoes were not even hot when they came out and already had a stale film on the exterior. The service was appalling. I had to beg for refills and the check. I will never come back here.

Zero stars... Horrible  bland food,  no appearance what  so ever  was not tasteful.  Server was extremely rude,  for our date night,  what a total waste of  $109.79.. I wish we had  played  slots with the  $ and we don't gamble.  Grade F.  Management clueless!!!

In this evening planning slow and relaxing dinner. Had a dessert ordered as my app. It arrived just as I got summoned to other duty. But I did take time, sorta, to wolf it down. Bananas Foster. Was pretty good in fact. But had to cancel everything else ordered. Great service.

Juicy delicious Prime Rib at a reasonable price.  Didn't go for the ambiance, it's at The Orleans for goodness sakes!  Just go and savor the meat don't go for your friggin 50th wedding anniversary people!!

Its an unpretentious but a step above a cafe restaurant. Booth seating, table cloth and lots of happy patrons. Entrees are served with corn chowder (lots of corn and ingredients over cream liquid) or salad doused in dressing. A plus for me, ask for dressing on the side if you're not like me. Long mini white garlic bread sticks and mini pretzel cigars with butter are openers. Special water is served here.  The prime rib of course was soft. Had an end cut and regular cut. Surprised how mild and lightly seasoned the meats were all around.   The salmon plate was a deceivingly large and thick cut of fish. Juicy. Tomato pilaf okay.  Service excellent. Desserts looked interesting and yummy, but we were too full. Glad to have tried the prime rib, but for me, the taste wasn't the super best. Also, it can get busy here so don't expect quick order and entree service. Its a take your time/enjoy and talk place.
Manager Craig and our waitress Donna went above and beyond great service!! The Loft is a MUST when in Vegas. Thank you Craig for such great service. I deffenitly will see you in July!!

Great, affordable, romantic, reasonable priced restaurant. They have awesome cuts of Prime Rib aged and cooked to perfection. The appetizers were sexy and displayed masterfully. The dessert cart makes you want to save room just to try these beautiful works of art. If you are in the Vegas area this is a must try restraurant. You will be glad you stopped by. It is located in the New Orleans with free parking.

bunch of friends and i ate here, because the buffet JUST closed...anyways, this is was close - and though it was not what we were craving for, the prime rib was really good.  I wouldnt go again, well because, i would plan my trip better to make it to the buffet on time.. 8o)

When you have prime rib in the name of your restaurant I have certain expectations going into it.  I tried the satay appetizer.  It was OK at best, dry and lacking flavor.  I ordered the medium cut prime rib cajun style.  It came out without the cajun seasoning, but that was quickly corrected.  The meat was done a little more than ordered, but not to the point it would dramatically affect the experience.  The meat was OK, not bad, not great.  The best part was the cajun seasoning.  It packed a lot of flavor and a nice kick.  Our server seemed overwhelmed and impatient.  He was short with us when we asked questions.  This is not a bad place, it just sets itself up for disappointment by including prime rib in the name.

The food here is actually really good...if the service could rise to acceptable I'd visit much more often. But it seems like every time I go the service heads downhill. Last night was horrible. Our (delicious!) grilled artichoke with lemon aioli appetizer came out and less than a minute later our salads were dropped. This was 30 minutes after we ordered...it seemed our salads were forgotten and nobody ever came close enough to our table for us to point this out. I think our server remembered when he brought out our appetizer. Entrees (which arrived about 45 minutes after our appetizer/salad course - with no sign of our waiter) were delicious. My husband had the filet Oscar, beef medallions topped with crab, asparagus and bearnaise sauce, and it was cooked perfectly. I had the top sirloin - very good. The garlic mashed potatoes are a favorite of ours and they didn't disappoint, especially with their yummy house gravy (you have to ask for it.)  We had a comp and we were paying the rest with a credit card. Our server insisted we fill out the credit card slip before he ran our card - he said to just subtract the amount of our comp. We did so, though it seemed like a weird way to pay at the end of a meal. He then returned to tell us we did the math wrong because we failed to subtract the amount of the tax that would come off with the comp. Seriously. It was ridiculous.  I used to really like this place, it was the first steak dinner my husband and I had in Vegas  - before we even moved here. The food is always yummy and the prices are very reasonable. The service, though, makes me question if I will ever return... Last night was simply awful.

Dry Aged Prime Rib!!! Very tasty and tender almost didn't need the knife. The blackened prime rib Cajun style was seasoned nicely without a huge puddle of Au Jus. Fresh shaved and creamy horseradish was hot. They had some nice sides and appetizers. Service was OK for drinks but there was a long wait in getting the bill trying to leave to catch the end of the NBA Finals. Overall I'd rate it a 3.75

Reading reviews on this place made it seem like this was the best spot in Las Vegas to get a prime rib and lobster dinner. Well...  The prime rib was pretty well prepared. We got the 24oz cut, medium rare, and split it between two (and an eighth; he had two bites, and just drank champagne for the rest of the evening) people. It came out more as a medium, but that's close enough. The menu claimed that there was an $8 dish splitting fee, and they didn't charge us for that, but the fact that it was inscribed in the menu bothered me.  They didn't have an explicit combination platter, so we had to spend an additional $20 for an 8oz lobster tail!  1. That's expensive. I get that Las Vegas is a little speckle of a city in the middle of a giant desert, but still.  2. It came out as rubber. It was also seasoned, which is frankly not how you prep a lobster tail.  We left full, but not quite satisfied.

we have eaten here many times. We like to stay at the Orleans because we find the gambling more generous than other casinos on the Strip. We would not go back as many times as we have (over a dozen) if their food and service were not top notch.  I have ever had a bad meal here. I do usually order the smallest cut of Prime Rib, but my dining companions have ordered around the menu and have had no complaints. My only complaint?  I never have had room to try dessert!

Several years ago we dined a few times at this restaurant and were not impressed, but I had points to burn and the current menu indicated 21-day, dry aged beef is now being served so we (actually I) decided to give it one more try - silly me.    Entrees include a choice of potato and salad with my wife choosing garlic mashed that were puree like and garlic-lite.  My baker with sour cream was better.  The salads were primarily iceberg lettuce that had been topped with diced tomatoes, a couple of olives and red onion tossed in for good measure and dressed with bottled blue cheese.    Though our slabs of cow were served medium rare as requested, it took a Herculean effort to just to cut them into bite sized pieces.  Our server seemed to be on auto pilot and never once stopped by to inquire if we need anything or had concerns.  This was proved to be by far the most disappointing meal of our entire 14 day vacation.

We had dinner here saturday night while staying at the Orleans for bowling. Service was spot on and the food was delicious! I ordered the gamblers cut and potato with everything. The prime rib was cooked perfectly, flavorful and tender! Nice size potato as well. My only small complaint was the tempura veggie appetizer still had a small bit of batter inside, maybe could have cooked a little longer. But all in all it was a good meal!

In on business, and wanted a great steak.  A local took us here.    Amazing NY Strip for $19(?).  Also came with salad and garlic mashed potatoes (or Baked)!!  Two others in our party had the 10oz Prime Rib, and it looked great as well.

The food, atmosphere were great. What wasn't so great was our server's attitude when we wanted to split the check. I've never had this issue before but she acted like our request was quite an imposition. She finally said she would take our cards if we write down what was to charged on each. Fine. Too bad she couldn't have said that nicely in the first place. I mean this is Vegas I've never had a problem with trying to give them my money before! It put a damper on what otherwise would have been a really  nice 50th bday celebration

Four of us family members decided to eat out for Christmas and we chose Prime Rib Loft.  We did need to make reservations.  Nice restaurant,   Very friendly staff and our waitress was very attentive to our needs.  The prime rib was VERY tender, moist and tasty, not to mention we received ample portions.  Three of us chose the baked potato and it was very good.  I was impressed with the potato because it was not only tasty but it was actually cooked all the way through.  Prices are fair for the portions.  Try this place, you won't be sorry!

If you like meat and potatoes, this place is for you. Good meat and sides for a decent price. The ambiance is calm and dark. It's in an area above and apart from the casino hustle-bustle. A good option for a romantic night out.

Yeah, there's no way that rib roast was "prime" nor was it "aged in house for 21 days". I think the middle cut is the best deal because a large portion of the 24 oz cut is bones.   For the price, these were two tough hunks of meat.   I was expecting to be blown away by it, but was not. It was a good meal, but we won't be back.   Cajun seasoning was good, but a tad overwhelming.   Baked potato was awesome. Apple pie was great.   We liked it but we didn't like it, like it.

This restaurant is now my absolute favorite prime rib place. My husband and I are visiting from Hawai'i and celebrated our anniversary by having dinner here.  Every staff member we encountered was wonderful. They were very professional and attentive to out needs.  The food was amazing. From the appetizers , to our 14oz prime rib was heavenly, and perfectly prepared. We had the sizzling apple caramel pie with vanilla bean ice cream for Dessert and it was so delish!

5 years in a row & always an amazing meal!  Prime rib or New York steak cooked to perfection, yummy garlic mash potatoes, backed potato, asparagus & mushrooms....all excellent & even better when Donna is your server....she's our favorite & the best!!! See u again next year!!!

I think the prime rib here is great an very good priced. You can get a 10-22 oz prime rib from 14-23$ I normally go for the gamblers cut which is about 14oz for 17$. They also have a cajun style prime rib that I don't care to much for. The baked potato are served with the toppings tableside. Everytime im in town I always make a trip here.

A highly enjoyable dining experience.  The food was prepared and presented perfectly.   Donna,  our server, is the consummate professional; we will ask for here again. Our party chose many different items from the menu, and all were well executed.   I highly recommend the Cotton Club cocktail.
Great  food. great atmosphere. lovely staff. I've been going to this place for years and it's always a good time. The prime rib is outstanding although this time it could have been hotter.

So mom and grandma in law wanted prime rib. The BF has been before and had a pretty good comped meal here so we head to the Loft instead of the usual buffets where they like to go.  The decor is dancing and musicians signatures and pictures on the wall. The food is rolled out onto carts so it has the very "old world", kinda dated way of doing things. It is a appropriate place to bring the parentals, grandparents, etc. I dunno, it just gave me that vibe and most of the other diners are older couples or middle adult groups.   Salad is pretty standard iceberg with some onions, cherry tomatoes and cucumbers, but all the veggies were fresh and crisp. They serve warm bread and butter that were pretty decent with a crisp outside and doughy inside.  Prime rib is the game so we all grabbed that. I think the prime rib was good- mine was juicy, tender and the right amount of fat on the rim. I got garlic mashed potatoes for my side- good garlic flavor but not much else. It needed more butter to make it creamier and it wasn't seasoned, but nothing a little salt and pepper I added myself couldn't cure. We ordered a side of the broccoli with beer cheese sauce. The sauce was good, but for everyone they wanted the broccoli cooked more. I like my vegetables a bit more crisp so I ate it up. Veggies were a big complaint of the table- mom in law was specially bummed that there's no creamed spinach, but we all love it so it was a big hitch for us. I would think that's a pretty standard accompaniment for prime rib but they only had broccoli, creamed corn, or mushrooms. I would think creamed spinach would fly out more than corn if they switched them.   We got a bananas foster to share. Good flavors, but needs a lot more ice cream....most the ice cream was melted and not enough to go around to break up that strong, very sweet Foster's sauce.   Service was pretty decent...we got refills and were checked on. We didn't wait on food too long.    I get why people like this place. Is it the absolute best prime rib available in Vegas? No, but you can't beat $14-22 for a slab with potato and soup/salad.  I feel you get good quality for your buck. It probably is one the better prime rib you can get in this price range and the best that Vegas has will be double the price. 4 people for $88 bucks is not bad at all. I don't know if this would be some place I'd go to that often...normally I would just go up a notch and get the best, but it was nice to try this. I left satisfied enough for what we paid and I guess that's what matters.

Old and tired a throw back to a day long gone by.  Needs an update to the decor and the menu/chef desperately. Servers and staff were great. Food was meh at best. Started with the artichoke crab dip appetizer. Came out quickly and with with only enough bread for about a third of the dip.  Had to ask twice for additional bread.  Hubby and I both had a salad.  Came with a entire slice of raw onion.  Inedible no reason to be on the salad. Cucumbers were not peeled,came with skin on, bitter....I had the 10oz cut of prime rib and added the lobster tail and chose the baked potato.  The beef was a bit over cooked for medium rare and not hot.  True to that cut of beef, very fatty and seasoned with large pieces of cracked pepper which made it incredibly terrible to eat if you bit into one.  The epic fail was the lobster tail.  It was so over cooked and was not one but two very small tails. Bottom line for $130 meal head to Lawry's where they specialize in prime rib and seem to have it figured out.

This is one of the best-kept secrets in Vegas if you're looking for your protein fix on a budget. My ex and I would always come in here and order the same thing- the 24 oz. cajun style bone-in prime rib TO SPLIT... for $24. And the kicker? Aside from the requisite bread basket (which was just OK) It normally comes with potato of choice (baked w/ all the fixings or french fries), vegetable and horseradish + side salad but every time we went and ordered it to split, they would split the potato between us, still give us a ton of fixings, AND give us our own side salads! Very nice service too.   The salads and potato aren't out of the ordinary, but they are simple, complete and done well, and the ambience is "upscale casual" (not even exactly dressy) but for the price (at about a little over $24 for the meal, we both just had iced water) we each got 12 oz. of meltingly tender, juicy, deliciously seasoned prime rib, a good size portion of potato and our own side salads. Count the excellent service and the white linen to boot, and it's a delicious steal of a meal. I recommend anyone try ordering it this way and they won't be disappointed... not for the price, anyway!

It gets 1 star because at least the meat was decent. But the server Ivan and his busser Carmen are the worst service I have had in Vegas. We are never coming back here. There are plenty of other places where the service won't spoil your meal.

Nice new surprise! Upstairs in the orleans. Big portions so hubby & I split as no where to put leftovers in hotel. Manager can by to check on everyone & Make good conversation. Tasted GREAT but server never smiled

So it's no Lawrys, for for less than $20 for prime rib, you can't go wrong.  I heard about this place from my cousin, and we all decided to try it.  It's off the strip, at The Orleans, but it's pretty good for it's price.  If you don't mind driving,  I'd reccomend it to people, and I'd probably go there again.  The service was very good and the wait staff was very attentive.

Shame on you yelpers! I came off of recommendations on yelp that said it was the best prime rib in Vegas.  If that's the best prime rib you've eaten in Vegas, I'm sorry.    The ambiance is nice, a bit dated, but it made me feel all grown up sitting at the fancy tables with the waiters bringing out plates with domes on top.  Nice touch.  But that's where the impressiveness ends.  The prime rib was fine.  Only a touch better than buffet prime rib.  The mashed potatoes were yum, but sadly we were only given one measly scoop.  I wanted more!  Anyway, I guess you can't expect much more for the price, huh? I'll shell out the extra dough next time for a quality piece of meat.

under $20 meals...decent prime rib...and cajun style is pretty good...located inside the orleans hotel....if you happen to be unlucky like me and end up staying at the orleans..it's worth a visit to this restaurant...

Buffet quality prime rib shouldn't have a loft named after it.  My friend ordered hers rare and we ordered ours medium rare.  It all came cooked the same.  Shrimp cocktails are skimpy and overpriced $14. Place has really gone downhill.
The 32 oz. med rare and a bottle of wine are great choice here. Delicious n great price. We love going here. Service always delightful

This review is long time coming. My husband I i eat here at least once a month. We went for New Year's Eve dinner last night and it was fabulous. The prime rib (English cut) was cooked to Perfection-like butter.  Artichoke appetizer was spot on.  My husband had the Creole Tenderloins tips and said the dish was great.  We've had in the past tempura vegetables and cauliflower bites which were yummy. I highly recommend this restaurant.  Service is excellent!

Def. not for kids! The menu is fairly small but food was decent. Prime rib was good and the baked potato was awesome! Also had the chicken pasta and that was pretty good. Great pace to go before the Hockey game!

don't be fooled by the Off Strip location, inside an old fogies casino, the Orleans.this was a winner. i did good finding this place.  came by for the boys steak dinner for March Madness. staying at the Rio but took the Gold Coast shuttle to here. very nice way to save cab money.  located at the far end of the casino floor, it's situated a top the floor with a great view of the gaming. surprisingly not busy during MM and spring break. got seated rather quickly and had the drinks coming shortly thereafter. the staff were very attentive and pleasant. the layout of the place is very classic, red velvet teeming from most parts of the restaurant.  very fair price for the bottle of Merlot that we ordered. even better pricing for the menu selections. i ordered the Beefeater. i wasn't messing around. at $27 for 24oz, it is a STEAL! almost half the price of Lawry's. i had initially thought that the quality would be sacrificed because of the price. boy, was i wrong. that cut of meat, on the bone, with the au jus was PERFECT. PERFECT i said! sooo mother effing good. i asked for green bean subsitution so as to make more room for the meat monolith. i ordered it medium and it was juicy and tender. they provide complimentary sourcream and horseradish which totally excentuates the flavors of the prime rib. damn, i can still taste it.  the boys loved their food as well. before i had a chance to mention it, a couple of my buddies already said that we're DEFINITELY coming back next year! and we will. YOU need to check this place out!

This is a cafeteria disguised as a nice restaurant! So disappointed!!!! To begin with, the presentation of the food is awful! It looks better at McDonald's!  My friend ordered the prime rib and ordered the potato gratin as a side... It was simply slapped on some plate and looked like regurgitation rather than actual potato gratin. It also tasted pretty bland and was just awful. The prime rib was just OK. The salmon was just OK and overcooked. The rice with tomato sauce, which also looked extremely unappetizing, was absolutely terrible and, while I'm at it, cold!Very underwhelmed. Will not likely be going back here. We are going to see a movie and decided to get dessert at the movie theater instead of the restaurant. Definitely overpriced and bill for two people for just ordering The prime rib and salmon was $61 with no alcohol yet just water. Big thumbs down. So not going back. The good: our server was nice and the restaurant looks nice... Until you taste the food.

We love prime rib. That is one of the main reasons we visit Vegas. We had a free room at The Orleans so we visited this lovely loft just before closing on a Monday night.  The server was super nice and attentive. The meal was wonderful and the decor was from the old restaurant that had been there. I think it was an Italian place at one time.  We will definitely return.

Prime Rib Loft in the Orleans Casino Hotel was our dinner selection tonight. A few tables overlook the casino with s great view of the huge Mardi Gras masks. Nice booths are by the perimeter of the space.  There were several cuts if Prime Rib  to choose from. We had an 8 oz cut and a 14 is cut. Prime rib was cooked perfectly  and served with a salad or corn chowder and a baked or A'Gratin  potato. The baked was much better with generous toppings for the long added potato. A'Gratin was under cooked and overall not flavorful.  The salads were crisp and fresh comprised of s nice variety of lettuces, tomatoes, cucumber slices, Onion strings, as olives.  Nice dressing selections. We chose blue cheese which was nice and not overpowering.  Our waiter was very efficient and rushed.   The hostess staff was somewhat rude. We had reservation but it did not seem to Matter. We asked for a table by the window and were told it was unavailable due to waitstaff. There must have been 20 tables and booths. Around the restaurant. But we were told to wait. Finally I asked about the table and we were shown to the booth. The hostess told us she had to wait to seat us when waitstaff was available The hostess and assistant were not welcoming but The food was worth the wait n

New look! Gone is the dark dungeon feel, walls are bright white. New carpet and gone are the fake foliage. And finally, a new menu. They have removed a few entre items like my favorite, filet Oscar and seafood appetizer.   They still have prime rib and it's still your choice of cut, seasoning (blackening) temperature.   But sides are now a choice of side salad or soup(no more lobster bisque) and baked potato ( no longer mashed).   Simpler choices, still good food. I had gamblers cut, medium rare. It was cooked perfect, side of horseradish. Baked potato fully loaded and corn soup. Servive was excellent and staff very attentive. Good place to come with friends and family or enjoy prime rib with the hubby!

The prime rib was excellent. But although three of us ordered it, the waiter only asked two of us if we desired horse radish. The potato au gratin was dry and sticky. The dinner salad was nice. But the shrimp scampi was the worst. Tasteless with over done shrimp.

Wife and I had the prime rib two nights ago, and the meat was absolute perfection  The newly renovated room is very nice,  good salad, tasty corn chowder, but the main event was that prime rib. We both agreed we have never had a more perfect prime ever.  If their consistancy can remain high, this will definately be our "go to" place to take friends for prime rib.
We met family here and it was a most wonderful dinner. Food was tasty and staff was super friendly! we will come again

Great value.  Good food at a rwasonable price. Prime rib is good. I would stay away from the soup of thw day. It is tgw same soup serced in the cafe with a healthier price tag.   The prime rib is excellent. The sea bass is good. It comes breaded in panko crumbs and sesame seed with an Asian themes sweet and sour sauce. I would recommend telling the server to have it broiled with butter and lemon. The fish is  good enough to stand on its own.  The baked potatoes are dressed table side which is a nice twist. You are able to control the amount of toppings.  The wine list could be better. But the wines they do have are grossly over priced, even by steakhouse standards. ($25 for a $5 Moscato. For the wife not me.)

I just was not impressed this time food was good but felt like our server wanted us in and out! It felt to me like she just did not want to be there. Plates got taken away to fast I was never asked if I was finished and bang my plate was gone. Good deal for staying at the Orleans but next time I am here I will try another Steak house it was a bit lack luster for my taste! I wish I knew our waitresses name. Our dinner was this past Sunday 04/13/2014 just not great!

I love this place. We always come here when win a little, as we always stay at the Orleans.  They just remodeled, and we brought friends who had never been to the Orleans. We were all impressed. Service from Lorenzo was top notch and the prime rib was so delicious! Comes with a salad and potato for like $26 bucks. Definitely worth trying if you want a fancy dinner.

We enjoy staying at the Orleans, we stayed there for the first time during Viva Las Vegas, and during that visit we discovered The Prime Rib Loft. We recently went back during the Kitchen and Bath Expo around Jan 15th and decided to stay at the Orleans, and have a nice quiet dinner at the Loft. We absolutely love it. For less than 100$ we had Rib Eye, bone in, Steak and Lobster and a bottle of Kendal Jackson Reserve Cab, along with Cesar Salad, and a table side made baked potato. It was awesome. The service was fantastic, our server was Saul, I would ask to sit in his station again. Accommodating but not intrusive, very well done. We were able to enjoy a relaxing meal, and have a little romance as well. Highly recommend it for anyone looking for a wonderful dinner and a little ambiance as well.

Everything was very good. I suggest the Cajun prime rib. You can get the seasoning on any cut a prime rib you get.. prices were very reasonable and the food was very comparable to much higher priced places in Las Vegas

Had the Orleans cut prime rib with the Caesar salad and mashed potatoes. There was nothing special about the salad, but the rest of the meal was good. The potatoes were phenomenal and the service was good. The price was good for the food also. My friend said his prime rib was a little dry, but mine was great

Great stuff...good prime rib! We were hungry and didn't want anything to do with the Mexican food below! LOL!   One gripe..I ordered my prime rib med rare...they served it medium. It was a bit dry.   Check out the cream corn, the prime rib and salad wasn't too bad. The bread sucked. Service good.  BTW....hostess asked us if we had reservations. Plenty of seating...and she still had to pencil us in with full name before she could seat us.

This is a great place to get steak and prime rib. Craig the manager is a guy that really pays attention to detail. This guy really makes the place awesome and makes you feel like you're the only people there. Our waitress Donna also did a great job and was very friendly and attentive to our table. The food was delicious and cooked exactly the way we ordered it. We will definitely be going back there every time we are in Las Vegas.
Adequate prime rib...someone recommended me the sesame crusted sea bass. Normally I dislike cooked fish,cept Chinese steamed. But it is amazing....drafting this between bites!

The food is pretty good. The service is very good. The décor is nice. The only problem is the noise level. We could barely carry on a conversation during dinner. We had a 5:30 reservation on a Wednesday night, and once the restaurant filled up it got LOUD. The other patrons were just plain loud. And it wasn't just one unruly table. Maybe it's a case of contagion, where everybody starts talking louder to compensate for the people around them (I know that we had to).....but the noise level gave the place all the ambience of a cafeteria.  All of our roast beef was more rare than we ordered.  We figured that they had heard "too well done" too often and made decision to err to the rare.....at least that's easily corrected.

SO reasonably priced!  Definitely not the BEST prime rib in Vegas, but dude, for $14 bucks, a 10-oz. piece of this prime rib is worth it to me.  I've gotten 16-oz. pieces for like $30 bucks and it was of similar quality to the Loft's.    We started off with the prime rib skewers with cheddar-beer sauce and I really liked it.  Tender pieces of prime rib and cheesy goodness, how can you resist?  You get a choice of soup or salad with your prime rib, and the BF got the cream of asparagus soup while I got a salad with ranch dressing.  I really liked his soup--a little smoky, and very light and tasty.  My salad was typical, but they overloaded it with too much dressing.  ASK FOR THE DRESSING ON THE SIDE!!  We both got the garlic mashed potatoes as a side, and they were also really good.  You can see the roasted garlic swirled throughout, and of course we ate those parts first!    As for dessert, we got the chocolate fondue.  It was thicker than what I was hoping for (they just melt chocolate chips....) but it wasn't horrible.  They give you cheesecake, pound cake, melon (weird), pineapple, strawberries, and bananas (I may have missed one thing in there).  I would definitely choose something else next time.  Overall, a great place to eat at if you want a multi-course meal for cheap.

Old school, old school, old school!!! When in Vegas you have to have at least one old school steak dinner and this is the place to do it. I found this place over a decade ago when attending a concert at The Orleans. It was so good... prime rib like velvet... and the service and ambiance was like a wonderful step back in time I return EVERY visit to Vegas (which is a couple times a year) as a matter of fact it's my tradition no matter who I'm with or why we are in LV to dine here our first night in town.  The tableside potato prep and the chilled bottled water just adds to the experience. I always get the prime rib and I'm never disappointed. I have dined here with a variety of people who have ordered a variety of entree options and all have agreed they have nothing to complain about just compliments.  I can't help but mention the cost.... I don't mind at all any amount of money for a memorable meal BUT if you can get a great memorable meal for a fraction of the cost of the celebrity steakhouses on the strip  and you aren't walking away still hungry this place is a fantastic value. Menu items are cheaper than some big box stores that aren't nearly as good and certainly don't have the old school vibe.  Though the Orleans is off the strip sister casino resorts on the strip offer a free shuttle or a taxi ride is only about 6-8$ The casino is older but still large and very lively so an after dinner stroll through the casino and maybe funky NOLA inspired cocktail before or after a nice dinner really rounds your visit out and makes the trek off the strip worth it!!

I'd give it a 4.5 Dinner 1/25/10 The Prime Rib Loft is up on the second floor.  It is a good sized open room with one end overlooking the casino floor.  The walls are painted with cabaret-nightclub scenes. We did not have reservations, but it was not very busy, but hey, it was 6:30 pm on a Monday evening.  This is still a pretty casual restaurant, so both of us felt comfortable wearing jeans.  We had a nice booth.  Service was excellent.  Hubby had the Bourbon Street Chicken, which he said was excellent.  He's not a big chicken fan either, but trying to follow Dr's orders somewhat.  I had the Filet of Beef Oscar.  Cooked perfectly and to die for.  So enjoyable.  Very, very good meal, but be aware - the garlic mashed potatoes SCREAM with garlic - too much for us.  The baked potato would have been a better choice for us.  $50.00 (excluding tip) for the two of us including a Bud & glass of White Zinfindel.  Ended up kinda funny neither of us ordered Prime Rib for which the restaurant is known for.......Highly recommend.

I enjoyed eating here.  We ordered the fried asparagus to start, and the dipping sauce was very flavorful. Make sure to give the asparagus time to cool.  They brought out my corn chowder, which was very creamy, and the wife got a salad.   The bread that cake out was good, a couple of breadsticks and some pretzel buns.  I ordered the "gamblers cut" prime rib which is 14 oz.  and the wife got the "the Orleans cut" (10 oz.) I was happy with the cuts, I only wish the beef was a tad juicier.  The service was excellent, can't beat it!

Great meal and affordable in Las Vegas. Located in the Orleans hotel. 4 of us with the 10 oz prime ribs. Including baked potato or ogratten potato Includes a salad and a $45 bottle of wine was only $155.  Very flavorful and filling.   Would highly recommend unless you was to dine on the strip and pay over 2× As much.

On a second dinner outing here with friends I was impressed by the great quality of the meaty and tasty House Shrimp Cocktail we were served with very good Cocktail Sauce; great-tasting and creamy Cream of Tomato Soup; and fine Dinner Salad with sliced tomatoes, Red Onions, lettuce, cucumbers, Black Olives, and Bleu Cheese Dressing.  Then I enjoyed an entree of a thin but fine pan-fried Filet of Beef Oscar with crab meat, drinkable Bearnaise Sauce, and a complimentary savory Brown Sauce.  Sauteed Mushroom Caps and a fine big Baked Potato with butter, chives, and bacon rounded out a really fine meal.  I also liked the Pretzel Bread but was just not enamored with the not real doughy-tasting rolls.  Except for having to ask for a water refill and more butter, service was very good, and our booth was quite comfortable.  There was little room remaining for dessert.  Another XXXX-1/2 star meal here!

Let's get down to business! This is one of my top favorite restaurants in Las Vegas no doubt. The flavor burst in my mouth with each bite of the succulent cajun spices smothered over prime rib excites me beyond belief, I should have really had a towel to sit on, eh hem....really a jean soaking experience to me lol. I always order the cajun style prime rib, nothing like it around I must say! This is another restaurant where in my experience during my meal I am once again finding myself moaning without control.  This place is great, my complete meal runs $14 bucks, a slab of cajun style prime rib, soup or salad and choice of side, giant baked, or roasted garlic mashed taters! A steal of a deal for such awesome flavor! Plus pre-meal bread is provided to snack on! Also ice cold complimentary imported bottled water served tableside wine style! A nice classy touch :) So is a good time to get your fill of water! Afterall your skin and kidney's are counting on you!
